title: Jean-Baptiste Regnault
text:
Jean-Baptiste Regnault (9 October 1754 – 12 November 1829) was a French <a href="Painting">painter</a>.
Biography.
Regnault was born in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, and began life at sea in a merchant vessel. At the age of fifteen his talent attracted attention, and he was sent to <a href="Italy">Italy</a> by M. de Monval under the care of <a href="Jean%20Bardin">Bardin</a>. After his return to Paris in 1776, Regnault won the <a href="Prix%20de%20Rome">Grand Prix</a> for his painting "Alexandre and Diogène", and in 1783 he was elected to the French <a href="Acad%C3%A9mie%20des%20Beaux-Arts">Académie des Beaux-Arts</a>. His diploma picture, "The" "Education of <a href="Achilles">Achilles</a> by <a href="Chiron">Chiron</a> the Centaur", is now in the <a href="Louvre">Louvre</a>, as also are his "Trois Grâces, Le Déluge, Descente de croix (Christ taken down from the Cross," originally executed for the royal chapel at <a href="Fontainebleau">Fontainebleau</a>) and "Socrate arrachant Alcibiade du sein de la Volupté."
His "L'origine de la peinture" and "L'origine de la sculpture, ou <a href="Pygmalion%20%28mythology%29">Pygmalion</a> amoureux de sa statue" are now at the <a href="Palace%20of%20Versailles">Palace of Versailles</a>.
Besides various small pictures and allegorical subjects, Regnault was also the author of many large historical paintings; and his school, which reckoned amongst its chief attendants <a href="Pierre-Narcisse%20Gu%C3%A9rin">Guérin</a>, <a href="Louis-Philippe%20Cr%C3%A9pin">Crepin</a>, Lafitte, <a href="Merry-Joseph%20Blondel">Blondel</a>, <a href="Robert%20Lef%C3%A8vre">Robert Lefèvre</a>, <a href="Henriette%20Lorimier">Henriette Lorimier</a> and Alexandre Menjaud, was for a long while the rival in influence of that of <a href="Jacques-Louis%20David">David</a>.
Besides Merry-Joseph Blondel, Pierre-Narcisse Guérin, Robert Lefèvre, and Henriette Lorimier, Jean-Baptiste Regnault's students include: <a href="Godefroy%20Engelmann">Godefroy Engelmann</a>, <a href="Louis%20Hersent">Louis Hersent</a>, <a href="Charles%20Paul%20Landon">Charles Paul Landon</a>, <a href="Hippolyte%20Lecomte">Hippolyte Lecomte</a>, <a href="Jacques%20R%C3%A9attu">Jacques Réattu</a>, <a href="Jean-Hilaire%20Belloc">Jean-Hilaire Belloc</a>.
Jean-Baptiste Regnault was married first to Sophie Meyer, then Sophie Félicité Beaucourt.
He died in Paris. He is buried in <a href="P%C3%A8re-Lachaise%20Cemetery">Père-Lachaise Cemetery</a>.
